The insect has a distinctive appearance, with a dark brown or black body and transparent, glassy-looking wings. Its eyes are prominent, and it possesses a long, piercing-sucking mouthpart that it uses to feed on the xylem (water-conducting tissue) of a wide range of host plants.

The glassy-winged sharpshooter is native to the southeastern United States but has since spread to other regions, including California and parts of Asia, through inadvertent human transportation. It is considered a significant threat to agriculture due to its ability to transmit the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which can cause devastating diseases in crops such as grapes, citrus, and almonds.

Effective management of the glassy-winged sharpshooter often involves integrated pest management strategies, including the use of biological control agents, targeted insecticide applications, and the implementation of cultural practices that aim to disrupt the insect's life cycle and reduce its population.
